description:
Abhay has ‘n’ number of toys with each toy having the amount of fun a[i]. Vijay is jealous of him and asks his father to buy him ‘m’ number of toys where m is greater than n. Each toy that belongs to Vijay has the amount of fun as b[i]. Vijay now selects ‘n’ number of toys from the ones he has to show to Abhay. He does not want their toys to be similar and thus wants to arrange them in such a way that the sum of the absolute difference of the toys at every index is maximum, meaning d=∑|ai−ci| where i ranges from 0 to (n-1) and you want to maximize d.
Return the maximum possible total absolute difference achievable.

Input Format:

First line contains two space separated integers ‘n’ and ‘m’ denoting the number of toys that Abhay and Vijay have respectively.

Second line contains ‘n’ space separated integers where each integer denotes the amount of fun of Abhay’s toy at ith position.

Third line contains ‘m’ space separated integers where each integer denotes the amount of fun of Vijay’s toy at ith position.

Output Format:

Return a single integer which is the maximum possible achievable ‘d’ where  d=∑|ai−ci| where i ranges from 0 to (n-1).
 
Sample Input:

3 5

1 6 4

3 5 12 11 4

Sample Output:

21

Explanation: We can select 12 at index 0, 3 for index 1 and 11 for index 2, so the resulting array would be [12,3,11] and the maximum of the sum of absolute difference of the fun of their toys would be |12-1| + |3-6| + |11-4| = 21 which is the maximum possible.

Constraints:

1<=n<m<=10^5

1<= a[i] <=10^5

1<= b[i] <= 10^5
title: Toys of Abhay and Vijay
